Cytokine and Growth Factor Reviews 12 (2001) 361-373
Survey
The GDNF/RET signaling pathway and human diseases
Masahide Takahashi *
Department of Pathology, Nagoya Uni6ersity Graduate School of Medicine, 65 Tsurumai-cho, Showa-ku, Nagoya 466-8550, Japan
Abstract
Glial cell line-derived neurotrophic factor (GDNF) and related molecules, neurturin, artemin and persephin, signal through a
unique multicomponent receptor system consisting of RET tyrosine kinase and glycosyl-phosphatidylinositol-anchored coreceptor
(GFRa1-4). These neurotrophic factors promote the survival of various neurons including peripheral autonomic and sensory
neurons as well as central motor and dopamine neurons, and have been expected as therapeutic agents for neurodegenerative
diseases. In addition, it turned out that the GDNF/RET signaling plays a crucial role in renal development and regulation of
spermatogonia differentiation. RET mutations cause several human diseases such as papillary thyroid carcinoma, multiple
endocrine neoplasia types 2A and 2B, and Hirschsprung's disease. The mutations resulted in RET activation or inactivation by
various mechanisms and the biological properties of mutant proteins appeared to be correlated with disease phenotypes. The
signaling pathways activated by GDNF or mutant RET are being extensively investigated to understand the molecular
mechanisms of disease development and the physiological roles of the GDNF family ligands. © 2001 Elsevier Science Ltd. All
rights reserved.

1. RET proto-oncogene
RET was originally identified as an oncogene acti-
vated by DNA rearrangement in 1985 [1 -3]. The RET
proto-oncogene encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase with
a cadherin-related motif and a cysteine-rich domain in
the extracellular domain and is located on chromosome
10q11.2. [4-7]. So far, three isoforms (short, middle
and long isoforms) that are generated by alternative
splicing in the 3% region have been cloned [8,9] (Fig.
1A).
RET expression was detected in human tumors of
neural crest origin such as neuroblastoma, pheochro-
mocytoma and medullary thyroid carcinoma [10 -12].
In rodent embryonic and adult tissues, it is highly
expressed in peripheral enteric, sympathetic and sensory
neurons as well as central motor, dopamine and nora-
drenalin neurons [13 -17], suggesting an important role
of Ret in differentiation and survival of these neurons.
In addition to the nervous system, Ret expression is
observed in the excretory system such as mesonephric
duct and branching ureteric bud during embryogenesis
although it almost disappears after birth [13,15]. Con-
sistent with its expression pattern, Ret knockout mice
showed lack of enteric neurons and superior cervical
ganglion as well as renal agenesis or dysgenesis [18,19].
Moreover, based on the precise studies of the mutant
mice, it was demonstrated that a common pool of
neural crest cells derived from the postotic hindbrain
gives rise to most of the enteric nervous system and the
superior cervical ganglion, depending on the c-Ret
function [19].
The RET proto-oncogene was identified as the
causative gene for human papillary thyroid carcinoma,
multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) types 2A and 2B,
and Hirschsprung's disease (HSCR) [20 -26]. Ten rear-
ranged forms of RET referred to as RET/PTC1-9 and
ELKS/RET have been cloned from sporadic and radia-
tion-associated papillary thyroid carcinomas [27 -29].
The intracellular domain of RET was fused to each
amino-terminal sequence of nine different activating
genes including H4 (for RET/PTC1), RIa (RET/
PTC2), ELE1(RET/PTC3 and RET/PTC4), RFG5
(RET/PTC5), hTIF (RET/PTC6), RFG7 (RET/PTC7),
kinectin (RET/PTC8), RFG9 (RET/PTC9) and ELKS
(ELKS/RET). Among these, the RET/PTC1 gene was
most frequently detected in sporadic papillary thyroid
carcinoma, although the frequency of RET rearrange-
ment was very different among countries. It was high
(10 -35%) in papillary carcinoma from Europe and the
United States [30,31] whereas it was very low (B 5%) in
those from Japan and Saudi Arabia [32 -34]. This may
be due to racial differences in the genetic background
or to environmental factors in these countries.
In addition, it turned out that RET rearrangement
occurred at high frequency (60 -70%) in papillary thy-
roid carcinoma of children from areas contaminated by
the Chernobyl nuclear reactor accident [35 -37]. In
contrast to sporadic papillary thyroid carcinoma from
the adult patients, a high predominance of RET/PTC3
(approx. a 3:1 ratio of RET/PTC3 and RET/PTC1)
was observed in these childhood papillary thyroid car-
cinomas. Interestingly, several reports demonstrated
that different types of RET rearrangement confer dis-
tinct phenotypic properties on neoplastic thyroid cells
[38 -41]. That is, RET/PTC3 was frequently found in
solid/follicular variant of papillary thyroid carcinoma
whereas RET/PTC1 was more common in typical pap-
illary type. Moreover, RET/PTC1 and RET/PTC3 ap-
peared to be associated with post-Chernobyl papillary
carcinomas of long and short latency, respectively [40].
Because similar RET rearrangement can be induced in
cell lines by in vitro X-irradiation and was found in
thyroid tumors from patients who had received external
radiation [42 -44], it seems likely that post-Chernobyl
papillary carcinomas developed as a direct consequence
of radiation exposure.
RET mutations identified in MEN 2A, MEN 2B and
HSCR, and their biological effects are described in
detail in the separate sections.

2. GDNF family ligands and their receptors
The glial cell line-derived neurotrophic factor
(GDNF) family ligands (GDNF, neurturin (NRTN),
artemin (ARTN) and persephin (PSPN)) form a new
family of neurotrophic factors that are structurally
related to transforming growth factor (TGF)-b [45-48].
These factors contain seven conserved, similarly spaced
cysteine residues, referred to as a cysteine knot motif,
and show approximately 40% amino acid identity each
other. GDNF, NRTN and ARTN were reported to
support the survival of a broad spectrum of both
peripheral and central neurons, whereas PSPN pro-
moted the survival of motor and nigral dopaminergic
neurons in culture as well as in vivo but did not support
the survival of any peripheral neurons examined.
Unlike ligands for other receptor tyrosine kinases,
the GDNF family ligands signal through a unique
multicomponent receptor complex consisting of glyco-
syl-phosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored coreceptor
(GFRa1 -4) as a ligand binding component and RET
receptor tyrosine kinase as a signaling component (Fig.
2) [48 -70]. GDNF, NRTN, ARTN and PSPN use
GFRa1, GFRa2, GFRa3 and GFRa4 as the preferred
ligand-binding receptors, respectively, although alterna-
tive ligand-coreceptor interaction also appears to occur
in culture. That is, GDNF can bind to GFRa2 and
GFRa3 in the presence of RET, and NRTN and
ARTN can bind to GFRa1 [48,55,57,58,60]. In addi-
tion, consistent with the fact that a cadherin-related
motif is present in the RET extracellular domain, Ca 2 +
ions were required for RET activation by GDNF and
NRTN [56].
Despite the promiscuity in ligand-receptor specificity
in culture, however, each of the GDNF family ligands
showed a rather specific role in vivo through the pre-
ferred GFRa -RET complex. Gdnf −/− or Gfra1 −/−
mice exhibited phenotypes similar to that of Ret −/−
mice [18,71-75]. These mice lacked enteric neurons
and showed renal agenesis or dysgenesis, although
the superior cervical ganglion that Ret −/− mice lacked
was normal or moderately affected in Gdnf −/− or
Gfra1 −/− mice. In Nrtn −/− or Gfra2 −/− mice, the
parasympathetic cholinergic innervation was dramati-
cally reduced in the lacrimal and submandibular sali-
vary glands as well as in the intestine [76,77]. Gfra3 −/−
mice exhibited severe defects in the superior cervical
ganglion whereas other ganglia appeared normal [78].

Taken together, it is likely that the preferred ligand-
GFRa -RET complexes have specific roles in vivo,
although Artn −/− , Pspn −/− or Gfra4 −/− mice have
not been reported yet.
3. The signaling pathways via GDNF/GFRa1/RET
complex
Since GDNF was discovered to represent a RET
ligand, extensive studies on intracellular signaling
through RET have been performed. Like other receptor
tyrosine kinases, RET can activate various signaling
pathways including RAS/extracellular signal-regulated
kinase (ERK), phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)/
AKT, p38 mitogen activated protein kinase (MAPK)
and c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) pathways [79-92].
It is well known that these signals are transmitted via
phosphotyrosine present in the intracellular domains of
activated receptors. RET short and middle isoforms
contain 16 tyrosine residues in their intracellular do-
mains and RET long isoform has two additional tyrosi-
nes in the carboxy-terminal tail. Among these tyrosines,
tyrosine 905, 1015, 1062 and 1096 represent binding
sites for GRB10, phospholipase Cg (PLCg), SHC/
SNT(FRS2)/Enigma and GRB2, respectively (Fig. 1A)
[82,93 -100]. The former three tyrosines are conserved
in all three RET isoforms but tyrosine 1096 is present
in the long isoform only. Although the sequence
around tyrosine 981 matches the consensus sequence
for binding of p85 subunit of PI3K, it does not appear
to directly bind to RET as described below.
Interestingly, our recent results demonstrated that all
of the RAS/ERK, PI3K/AKT, p38MAPK and JNK
pathways are activated mainly through tyrosine 1062
that is a binding site for SHC adaptor proteins [92].
After binding of SHC to tyrosine 1062 following
GDNF stimulation, SHC further associates with
GAB1/2 adaptor proteins and GRB2/SOS complex,
leading to the activation of PI3K/AKT and RAS/ERK
signaling pathways, respectively (Fig. 2). GAB1/2 di-
rectly associates with p85 subunit of PI3K, resulting in
the activation of PI3K [86,92,101]. However, the fact
that mutation of tyrosine 1062 did not completely
abolish the activation of RAS/ERK and PI3K/AKT
pathways suggested the presence of alternative path-
ways. Besset et al. [101] reported that because AKT but
not ERK activation was almost completely abolished
by double mutations of tyrosines 1062 and 1096, bind-
ing of GRB2/GAB2 complex to tyrosine 1096 may
offer an alternative route for activation of the PI3K/
AKT signaling pathway. Unexpectedly, although ty-
rosine 1096 represents a binding site for GRB2 (Fig.
1A), it does not appear that GRB2 biding to this
tyrosine plays an important role in the activation of the
RAS/ERK signaling pathway [92,101]. We and others
found that the RAS/ERK and PI3K pathways via
tyrosine 1062 are important for activation of CREB
and NFkB transcription factors, respectively, [92] as
well as for PC12 cell survival (Fig. 2) [102]. In addition,
RAS activation was essential for RET-induced cell
differentiation in PC12 cells [103] whereas PI3K signal-
ing independent of AKT was necessary for lamellipodia
formation that is a critical event in neuritegenesis (Fig.
2) [81,100].
SNT/FRS2 is a lipid anchored docking protein with
a phosphotyrosine-binding (PTB) domain. We recently
found that SNT/FRS2 binds to tyrosine 1062 of RET
in a GDNF-dependent manner and is associated with
GRB2/SOS complex but not GAB1, suggesting that
SNT/FRS2 may be involved mainly in the activation of
the RAS/ERK signaling pathway (Fig. 2) [104]. These
findings imply that tyrosine 1062 in RET provides a site
for the interaction of multiple signaling molecules and
that the balance of SHC and SNT/FRS2 binding may
affect the nature of the intracellular signaling in RET-
expressing cells. Interestingly, it was suggested that
RET which moved to lipid rafts following GDNF
stimulation triggers the signal through SNT/FRS2
whereas RET outside rafts triggers it through SHC
(Fig. 2) [105].
The binding affinity of SHC and SNT/FRS2 to RET
was different among three isoforms, although the con-
sensus sequence for binding of the phosphotyrosine
binding (PTB) domain of SHC and SNT/FRS2 is con-
served in the sequence amino-terminal to tyrosine 1062
in them (Fig. 1B) [104]. Their binding affinity to RET
middle isoform was significantly low compared with
that to RET short and long isoforms. Because the
sequences carboxy-terminal to tyrosine 1062 were dif-
ferent among three isoforms (Fig. 1B), this suggested
the importance of these carboxy-terminal sequences for
the binding of SHC and SNT/FRS PTB domains [104].
In addition, their low binding affinity to RET middle
isoform was in agreement with the fact that transform-
ing activity of RET middle isoform with MEN2A mu-
tation was much lower than that of RET short or long
isoform with MEN2A mutation [106].
The p38MAPK, JNK and MEK5/big mitogen-acti-
vated protein kinase 1 (BMK1) pathways are also
activated through tyrosine 1062 [92,107]. Although it is
unknown whether SHC or SNT/FRS2 binding to ty-
rosine 1062 is required for activation of these pathways,
activation of the JNK pathway by mutant RET protein
was shown to be induced via Rho/Rac-related small
GTPase, such as CDC42 [84]. Because it is possible that
the PI3K signaling regulates the functions of these
small G proteins following GDNF stimulation, the
JNK pathway may be downstream of PI3K. In addi-
tion, tyrosine phosphorylation of several other signal-
ing molecules including FAK, paxillin, p130 CAS and
p62Dok was induced by PI3K signaling [85,86]. Among

these proteins, phosphorylation of FAK was Rho-de-
pendent (Fig. 2) whereas phosphorylation of paxillin
and p130 CAS was Rho-independent.
More recently, the presence of RET-independent sig-
nals triggered by GDNF was suggested [88,108].
GDNF was able to activate Src-type kinases and PLCg
in sensory neurons from Ret −/− mice and Src kinases
were associated with GFRa1 in Triton-insoluble frac-
tions including lipid rafts. GDNF also promoted the
survival of cultured neuronal cells expressing GFRa1
but lacking RET, and induced CREB and Fos activa-
tion in them [88,108]. Because the phenotypes of
Gdnf −/− and Gfra1 −/− mice were very similar to that
of Ret −/− mice, these findings suggested that RET-in-
dependent GDNF signaling through GFRa1 may play
a role postnatally in neuronal functions rather than
neuronal differentiation during embryogenesis.
4. RET mutations and multiple endocrine neoplasia
type 2
4.1. RET mutations in MEN 2
Germline RET mutations are responsible for devel-
opment of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) types
2A and 2B and familial medullary thyroid carcinoma
(FMTC) [21 -24,109]. MEN2A and MEN2B are auto-
somal dominant cancer syndromes characterized by
medullary thyroid carcinoma and pheochromocytoma.
In addition to these, parathyroid hyperplasia develops
in 10-30% of the affected members of MEN 2A
families. MEN 2B patients are known to develop
medullary thyroid carcinoma with an earlier age of
tumor onset and show a more complex phenotype
including ganglioneuromatosis of the gastrointestinal
tract and mucosa, medullated corneal nerves, and mar-
fanoid habitus. FMTC is characterized by medullary
thyroid carcinoma only that usually develops at a later
stage in life.
MEN2A mutations have been identified in one of six
cysteine residues (codons 609, 611, 618 and 620 in exon
10, and codons 630 and 634 in exon 11) in the RET
extracellular domain [109]. In FMTC, point mutations
were detected at cysteine residues like MEN2A muta-
tions or at codon 768, 804 or 891 (exons 13, 14 or 15)
in the tyrosine kinase domain [109]. In addition, a 9 or
12 base pair duplication in exon 11 and a 9 base pair
duplication in exon 8 that create an additional cysteine
residue were reported in two MEN 2A families and one
FMTC family, respectively [110-112]. Although mis-
sense mutations at codon 790 or 791 were reported in
five German FMTC or MEN 2A families [113], these
have not been identified in families from any other
countries.
Two missense point mutations at codon 918 (exon
16) or codon 883 (exon 15) were associated with MEN
2B [109]. Methionine at codon 918 and alanine at
codon 883 were replaced with threonine and phenylala-
nine (designated M918T and A883F), respectively.
More than 95% of MEN 2B patients are accounted for
by the M918T mutation but fewer than 4% are ac-
counted for by the A883F mutation. Recently, double
germline mutations at codon 804 and 806 were reported
in a Japanese patient that had clinical features charac-
teristic of MEN 2B including medullary carcinoma,
mucosal neuroma, marfanoid habitus, thickening of
corneal nerves (grade 4) and medullary hyperplasia of
bilateral adrenal gland [114,115].
4.2. Genotype-phenotype correlations in MEN 2
We and others demonstrated that all of MEN2A,
MEN2B and FMTC mutations except mutations of
codons 790 and 791 can induce constitutive activation
of RET proteins [115-123]. As a consequence, RET
became the first case that gain-of-function mutations of
a proto-oncogene were implicated in the etiology of an
inherited cancer syndrome. Cysteine mutations iden-
tified in the MEN 2A and FMTC families activate RET
by inducing its disulfide-linked homodimerization
(Table 1) [116,117]. These cysteine residues are thought
to be normally involved in the formation of intramolec-
ular disulfide bonds that are necessary for appropriate
tertiary structure of the RET extracellular domain. Our
hypothesis on RET activation by the MEN2A mutation
is that when a cysteine residue is mutated to a non-cys-
teine residue, a partner cysteine that is involved in the
formation of a disulfide bond may become free and
form an aberrant intermolecular disulfide bond between
two mutant RET, leading to the constitutive activation
of intrinsic tyrosine kinase.
In the cases of MEN2B mutations identified in the
tyrosine kinase domain, RET was activated in a
monomeric form, probably due to a conformational
change of catalytic core of the kinase domain [117-
119]. Several reports suggested that the MEN2B muta-
tions alter the substrate specificity of the RET protein
[86,117,124,125], although which signaling pathway is
important for development of the MEN 2B clinical
phenotype is still unclear. In addition, we found that
tyrosine residues in the kinase domain essential for
transforming activity are different between RET-
MEN2A and RET-MEN2B mutant proteins. That is,
tyrosine 905 and tyrosines 864 and 952 were required
for the activity of RET-MEN2A and RET-MEN2B
proteins, respectively (Table 1) [119,123]. It is well
known that a tyrosine residue is conserved in all ty-
rosine kinases at the same position as tyrosine 905 in
RET and plays an crucial role in their biological and
biochemical activities. Because the MEN2B mutations

at codons 918 and 883 are located near tyrosine 905, a
conformational change in the region including these
amino acids may result in the shift of tyrosine residues
(tyrosine 905 tyrosines 864 and 952) that are required
for transforming activity of the RET-MEN2B mutant
protein.
Recently, a novel V804M/Y806C double mutation
was identified in a Japanese female MEN2B patient
[114]. These two mutations were present in the same
allele and the Y806C mutation was inherited from her
father who showed no symptoms of tumor. On the
other hand, the V804M mutation was a de novo muta-
tion in the patient. Transforming activity of RET with
the V804M/Y806C double mutation was approximately
8 -13-fold higher than that of RET with a single
V804M or Y806C mutation [115]. Moreover, we found
that tyrosines 864 and 952 are also important for
transforming activity of RET with this double mutation
as observed for RET-M918T and RET-A883F mutant
proteins, suggesting that these three RET-MEN2B mu-
tant proteins have similar biological properties (Table
1) [115]. This was the first example to show that two
germline RET mutations in the same allele were respon-
sible for development of MEN 2B.
Cysteine mutations in the RET extracellular domain
sometimes induce the FMTC phenotype. Of these mu-
tations (codons 609, 611, 618, 620, 630 and 634), ap-
proximately 30% occurred at codon 634 and more than
60% occurred at codons 609, 618 and 620 in FMTC
families [126]. This is in contrast with the fact that
cysteine 634 mutations were detected in approximately
85% of the MEN 2A families. The transforming activity
of RET with codon 609, 618 or 620 mutation was
significantly low compared with that of RET with
codon 634 mutation (designated RET-Cys634) (Table
1), resulting from the impairment of cell surface expres-
sion of the former mutant proteins [121,127]. Their low
transforming activity may predispose to development of
FMTC rather than MEN 2A. Although three kinase
domain mutations at codons 768, 804 and 891 identified
in some FMTC families activate RET in a monomeric
form like the MEN2B mutations, the transforming
activity of these FMTC mutant proteins was also very
low compared with that of RET-Cys634 or RET-
MEN2B protein (Table 1) [123]. Taken together with
the fact that pheochromocytoma does not always de-
velop in the affected members of MEN 2A, low trans-
forming activity of the FMTC mutant proteins
supported the view that the threshold of transformation
is low in thyroid C cells and relatively high in adrenal
chromaffin cells. As observed for RET with cysteine
mutations, tyrosine 905 was required for transforming
activity of the RET-FMTC proteins with codon 768,
804 or 891 mutation (Table 1) [123], suggesting these
FMTC mutations may not alter the substrate specificity
of the RET protein.
In addition, we found that mutation of tyrosine 1062
markedly decrease the transforming activity of all of
RET-MEN2A, RET-MEN2B and RET-FMTC mutant
proteins (Table 1) [93,115,123]. This finding is reason-
able because many signals including the RAS/ERK,
PI3K/AKT, JNK, p38MAPK and MEK5/BMK1 path-
ways are activated through tyrosine 1062 as mentioned
above (Fig. 2) [91,92,107]. Recently, Segouffin-Cariou
and Billaud [91] reported the importance of the PI3K/
AKT signaling pathway for transforming activity of
RET-MEN2 proteins, although further investigation of
intracellular signaling pathways activated by mutant
RET will be required to deeply understand the molecu-
lar mechanisms of tumor development by RET
mutations.

5. Transgenic mouse models for MEN 2A and MEN2B
To date, several transgenic mouse models for MEN
2A or MEN 2B have been generated by introducing
mutant RET genes. Mice expressing a RET-MEN2A
gene under the control of the rat calcitonin gene-related
peptide/calcitonin (CGRP/CT) promoter or Moloney
murine leukemia virus long terminal repeat (LTR) have
been produced [128,129]. In case the CGRP/CT pro-
moter was used to specifically express the transgene in
thyroid C cells, animals of two transgenic mouse lines
displayed C cell hyperplasia and subsequently devel-
oped medullary thyroid carcinoma with a complete
penetrance at 14 months of age [128]. Despite the
transgene expression, no pathological change was ob-
served in the adrenal gland of transgenic mice. It was
suggested that this may be due to an insufficient level of
the RET-MEN2A mutant protein to exert an effect in
the adrenal gland.
We recently generated transgenic mice carrying the
RET-MEN2A gene under the control of MoMuLV
LTR [129]. They also developed C cell hyperplasia as
early as 4 weeks and developed medullary thyroid
carcinoma with a complete penetrance at 6 months of
age. Interestingly, although the mice expressed the
transgene and its protein product at high levels in
several tissues including brain, liver, and heart, no
pathological change was found in these tissues. RET
dimerization and its complex formation with Shc and
Grb2 adaptor proteins were detected in medullary car-
cinoma but not in brain, liver and heart of transgenic
mice. Our experimental results suggested the possibility
that high levels of expression of certain cell surface
proteins such as GFRa may interfere with dimerization
of the RET-MEN2A protein in brain, liver and heart,
leading to tissue-specific tumor development in trans-
genic mice. In this respect, it is interesting to note that
overexpression of Leukocyte Common Antigen-Related
(LAR) protein tyrosine phosphatase on the cell surface
also interfered with dimerization of the RET-MEN2A
protein and suppressed its oncogenic activity [130].
Thus, it seems likely that expression of certain cell
surface proteins in the affected cells modifies the clinical
phenotypes of MEN 2 syndromes by impairing the
RET dimerization.
Transgenic mice expressing the RET-MEN2B gene
were produced using the human dopamine b-hydroxy-
lase (DbH) promoter or the human calcitonin gene
promoter [131-133]. The DbH promoter was expected
to efficiently function in the sympathetic and enteric
nervous systems as well as the adrenal gland. DbH-
RET-MEN2B transgenic mice developed benign neu-
roglial tumors, histologically identical to human
ganglioneuromatosis, in the sympathetic ganglia and
adrenal medullae, although malignant transformation
never occurred. On the other hand, the enteric nervous
system was not affected in these mice [131]. This resis-
tance may reflect, in part, a relatively low level of the
DbH promoter activity in enteric neurons. Unexpect-
edly, mice expressing high levels of the DbH-RET-
MEN2B gene displayed renal agenesis or dysgenesis as
observed in Ret-knockout mice. Gestblom et al. [132]
suggested that renal malformation could be secondary
to the expression of the RET-MEN2B transgene by
hyperplastic sympathoadrenal tissues that competes
with endogenous renal Ret for Gfra-1 or other signal-
ing components.
In case the human calcitonin gene promoter as a
regulatory unit was used for the expression of the
RET-MEN2B gene, one transgenic mouse line that
developed C cell hyperplasia at a high frequency was
established, although development of medullary thyroid
carcinoma was observed in only 13% of mice [133].
Taken together with the fact that the CGRP/CT-RET-
MEN2A transgenic mice mentioned above had the vari-
able latency period for medullary carcinoma, this
finding supported the view that additional genetic alter-
ations are required for malignant transformation of
thyroid C cells.
More ideal transgenic mouse model for MEN 2B was
generated by introducing the mutation into mouse en-
dogenous Ret gene [134]. Gene targeting techniques in
conjunction with Cre/loxP site-specific recombination
were used to introduce the MEN2B (Met919Thr) muta-
tion into the corresponding exon of the mouse Ret
gene. Heterozygous mutant mice displayed hyperplasia
of thyroid C-cells and adrenal chromaffin cells, al-
though they were less severely affected than humans
with MEN 2B. Mutant homozygotes resembled the
human syndrome more closely, displaying an earlier
incidence and increased severity of C-cell hyperplasia
and chromaffin cell hyperplasia that progressed to
pheochromocytoma. However, these homozygotes did
not develop medullary thyroid carcinoma and gan-
glioneuromatosis of the gastrointestinal tract and mu-
cosa that are characteristic of human MEN 2B,
suggesting that the accumulation of secondary genetic
alterations is also required for development of
medullary carcinoma in these mice. Moreover, neuro-
matous enlargement of sympathetic ganglia as well as a
male reproductive defect were observed in ho-
mozygotes. They exhibited normal mouting and pro-
duced mature sperm. Because erectile dysfunction with
a neuroloical basis is common in human with MEN 2B,
a likely explanation was that mutant mice also had a
erectile defect [134]
6. Loss-of-function RET mutations in Hirschsprung's
disease
Hirschsprung's disease (HSCR) is a congenital mal-

Fig. 3. Mechanisms of RET dysfunction by HSCR mutations. Three
representative mechanisms of RET dysfunction by the designated
HSCR mutations are shown. In addition to these, we recently found
that several mutations (E762Q, S767R, R972G, M980T) identified in
the kinase domain severely impaired the PLCg signaling pathway in
a neuronal cell line [145].
of the tyrosine kinase family [145]. Fourth, some muta-
tions (E762Q, S767R, R972G, M980T) that were also
identified in the kinase domain severely impaired the
activation of PLCg in SK-N-MC human neuronal cells,
whereas the RAS/ERK and PI3K/AKT pathways were
slightly affected [145]. Taken together, these results
suggested that several signaling pathways including
RAS/ERK. PI3K/AKT and PLCg pathways may coop-
eratively function for normal development of the en-
teric nervous system.
Recently, Bordeaux et al. [146] reported that the
expression of normal RET kinase can induce apotosis
and this pro-apoptotic effect is inhibited by GDNF. In
addition, It turned out that RET is a substrate for
caspase-3 and this caspase cleavage is required for its
pro-apoptotic effect. All of five HSCR mutations exam-
ined impaired GDNF-control of RET pro-apoptotic
activity [146], implying that HSCR may result from
apoptosis of RET-expressing enteric neuroblasts.
7. Cosegregation of MEN 2A/FMTC and HSCR
It has been reported that HSCR and MEN 2A/
FMTC co-segregate in a sizeable fraction of families
and that affected members carry a single RET muta-
tions within the coding sequence [147,148]. Screening of
the RET gene in these families led to the identification
of point mutations at either cysteine 609, 618 or 620
that segregated with both HSCR and MEN 2A/FMTC
phenotypes. These mutations were identical to previ-
ously described MEN2A/FMTC mutations and no ad-
ditional mutations were found after sequencing of the
entire RET coding region. We and others demonstrated
that these mutations markedly decreased the RET cell
surface expression like the HSCR mutations identified
formation associated with aganglionosis of the gas-
trointestinal tract. Based on the length of the agan-
glionic segment, it is classified into two groups: patients
with aganglionosis as far as the rectosigmoidal junction
(short segment type) and patients with aganglionosis
beyond the rectosigmoidal junction (long segment
type). RET mutations appeared to account for approxi-
mately 50% of familial and 10-20% of sporadic cases
of HSCR, most of which (approx. 75%) were associated
with long segment HSCR. A variety of missense, non-
sense and frameshift mutations have been identified
along the whole coding sequence of RET [25,26,135-
137].
Based on functional analyses of RET with HSCR
mutations, it turned out that at least four mechanisms
of RET dysfunction are responsible for development of
HSCR. First, most mutations identified in the RET
extracellular domain markedly impaired the RET cell
surface expression, probably due to incorrect folding of
the RET protein (Fig. 3) [138-140]. As a result, the low
amount of the RET protein at the cell surface would
transmit a signal below the threshold required to elicit
a trophic response in enteric neuroblasts during em-
bryogenesis. It is interesting to note that long segment
HSCR mutations more severely impair the RET cell
surface expression than short segment HSCR mutation,
suggesting that the levels of the RET cell surface ex-
pression may correlate to the severity of HSCR [139].
Second, a couple of mutations identified in the carboxy-
terminal tail impaired the SHC binding to RET (Fig.
3), thus resulting in RET-mediated signaling defect
[106,141]. As mentioned above, SHC binding is respon-
sible for at least two major signaling pathways includ-
ing RAS/ERK and PI3K/AKT pathways that may play
a crucial role in neuronal differentiation and survival
(Fig. 2). Third, several mutations in the kinase domain
almost completely abolished the RET tyrosine kinase
activity (Fig. 3) [142-145]. These mutations occurred at
amino acids that are highly conserved among members

function.

in the RET extracellular domain, whereas they were
also able to induce the aberrant formation of disulfide-
linked RET homodimers at low levels, leading to con-
stitutive activation of the mutant RET proteins (Fig. 4)
[121,149,150]. Cysteine 609, 618 or 620 mutation might
alter the folding of RET, partially interfering with RET
maturation, intracellular trafficking or stable expression
at the plasma membrane. Although the level of RET
dimerization was low, the activity of these mutant RET
could be sufficient to trigger the development of
medullary thyroid carcinoma as well as pheochromocy-
toma. On the other hand, the decrease of RET cell
surface expression in enteric neuroblasts during em-
bryogenesis would transmit a signal below the
threshold necessary for their complete differentiation or
for prevention of their inappropriate apoptosis. Thus, it
seems likely that a single mutation at codon 609, 618 or
620 functions as either a gain-of-function mutation or a
loss-of-function mutation, depending on the cell types
expressed (Fig. 4) [150].
8. Concluding remarks
In the past 10 years, studies on RET signaling have
provided us with many interesting findings on kidney
morphogenesis, neurogenesis and oncogenesis. In addi-
tion, it was recently reported that GDNF regulates
differentiation of spermatogonia, suggesting the possi-
bility that reduced spermatogonia pools in infertile men
might be restored by activating the RET signaling [151].
However, despite these extensive studies of the signaling
pathways mediated by activated RET, we still do not
know precisely how each signaling component con-
tributes to these biological events. A deeper under-
standing of the signaling network will be necessary not
only elucidate to the molecular mechanisms of cell
growth, differentiation and survival but also to develop
therapeutic strategies for human diseases caused by
RET mutations.
